So on the PTG we agreed to
* add new notifications for share attach and share detach
* extend the instance update notification with the share mapping information.

Here are the patches that added the volume attach/detach versioned notification https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/401992 / https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/408676

And here are the patch that added the BDM to the instance notifications https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/448779 . Note that later this code was fixed not to re-load the BDM from the DB if the BDM is already available in the calling context: https://review.opendev.org/q/topic:bug%252F1718226

As we shortly discussed in the PTG we might want to follow the pattern that make the share mapping optional in the instance payload via a config option if providing the share_mapping information needs an extra DB query just for the notification payload.

Also here are some background information about versioned notifications
* https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WFq5JWXa9AM
* https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/admin/notifications.html
* https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/mitaka/implemented/versioned-notification-api.html

If you configure file backing memory on the host it is detected by the libvirt drv  and it enables the trait COMPUTE_MEM_BACKING_FILE.

Then if you add the corresponding extra_spec, it allows the instance to be scheduled to a host with the both traits enabled, making sure you could use virtiofs.

Thanks Sean. I think what you suggest make sense. Let's decouple the host mount state of the share and the status of the SM (ShareMapping). This means that we need to redefine the possible states of the SM as you suggested above.

Then we have to think again when a share can be unmounted from a host. I think we have two options:
a) unmount if there are no SM objects(whit any status) pointing to an instance that is scheduled to this host. (When we will implement move operations for VMs with shares we probably need to extend this logic to look for instances with active migration records and the source and dest hosts in there)

b) unmount if the only SM objects related to this host (via instances as in #a)) are all in reserved or error status. I.e. unmount if no other active SM on this host.

The #a) is definitely simpler to implement but it keeps the share mounted even if only reserved or error SMs are "using" it. Which is probably not a problem but worth mentioning.

I was not after changing the name, sorry. I wasn't clear. I just wanted to make sure we agree on the meaning of the states. Based on your answer I think we agree. But I have a follow up question. 

As the state is tight to the compute host but also the state is stored per instance-share association we need to care about batch update of states. 

I.e.: 
There are two stopped VMs (VM1, VM2) on the same host. User attach the share same to both VMs. Both ShareMapping (SM1, SM2) objects will be in inactive state. Then the user starts the VM1. Nova attaches the share to the compute host successfully. Nova updates SM1.state to active. Nova nova needs to also update SM2.state to active as the underlying share is now mounted to the host, even though the VM2 is still STOPPED.

Do you agree?

Thanks for checking! Currently manila has no feasible way for a share to be "locked" to prevent its deletion. A privileged user (project/cloud administrator) can put the share in a maintenance or busy state and effectively make it undeletable. However, this approach isn't useful in this context.

The main problem behind manila API not supporting an "attached" status is because the underlying NAS protocols cannot discern if a client is actively "connected" to a NAS server. 


However, I do like your proposal of adding a tenant driven "busy" state. One way of doing so can be via the interactions already being done here. Nova will need to perform an "access-allow" operation (POST /shares/<id>/action {'allow_access': {...}) prior to attaching a share. In this call, if you could pass down some metadata, manila can put a "lock" on that share. Later, when a request comes to detach a share (POST /shares/<id>/action {'deny_access': {<id>}), manila can "unlock" the share. 

If this seems fine to you, i can implement this in manila.

no, this target is being smart defined by the bottom patch

we probably only need to cover both for Wallaby, where we do support modular and monolitic libvirt cases?

so for master, I can put it as

ExecStart=/bin/podman exec nova_virtproxyd /bin/rm -f /var/lib/libvirt/libvirt-guests
so the question is, should I restore these commands and the service unit lost after the docker to podman switch?

don't think we need that start as nova-compute service is responsible to start the instances. But we need to make sure nova-compute is down before libvirt-guests shutdown the instances. if the instance gets shut down and nova-compute is up, the instances gets set to off in the DB and on the host boot it won't get started

this creates wrong shutdown dependency, compare it to what we have for tripleo-container-shutdown-service [0]:

docker & pacemaker.service -> (<-after) tripleo-container-shutdown -> (before) -> shutdown.target

and here it will create:
systemd-machined & virt-guest-shutdown empty target (<- after/requires) tripleo_nova_libvirt_guests.service, calls /usr/libexec/libvirt-guests.sh shutdown -> (before) -> tripleo_nova_compute.service (should be requires!?)

[0] https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ansible/src/branch/master/tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_container_manage/files/tripleo-container-shutdown-service#L8

so basically this is:

tripleo_nova_compute.service -> (<- before) tripleo_nova_libvirt_guests.service, calls /usr/libexec/libvirt-guests.sh shutdown -> (after/requires) -> systemd-machined & virt-guest-shutdown empty target & tripleo_nova_libvirt.target

and this matches:
n-cpu -> after+wants -> libvirt target

and also follows the established pattern with tripleo-container-shutdown-service:
shutdown.target -> (<- before) tripleo-container-shutdown, docker only -> (after) docker & pacemaker.service

So we don't need that stop nova_compute command.
...well right, stopping nova compute unit should work automatically on systemd level

monolithic is deprecated and only backports are expected as of now

Hi Andrii, could you please help to review this patch？

At this point I think upstream should be closer to what is documented.
Wallaby should be deployed using deployed ceph, which means that any attempt to run a fresh deployment (using the overcloud deploy cmd) should be blocked unless it's an Upgrade from the previous release to Wallaby.
Maybe this change should be made downstream only since we deprecated ceph-ansible in wallaby but didn't remove it.
Thanks you Francesco for this patch. I think it will be very useful. I still think we should only do it downstream however.

> > Do we want to support (upstream of course), fresh deployment based on ceph-ansible ?
> 
> Yes, because we said we would when W GA'd. Upstream W is a transitional release.
> 
> https://docs.openstack.org/project-deploy-guide/tripleo-docs/latest/features/ceph_config.html#deploying-an-overcloud-with-ceph
> 
> The above doc should be updated (cephadm can do it all now) but we pledged to support both cephadm and ceph-ansible in wallaby upstream so we shouldn't retroactively remove that support. Downstream is a different story so doing this downstream is justified IMO.

Following up on the above, here's a patch to update the doc accordingly (since cephadm can do it all now).

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-docs/+/839096/1/deploy-guide/source/features/ceph_config.rst

This change doesn't remove it, for an existing environment deployed using ceph-ansible this change just remind that an upgrade (to wallaby) should be performed. When the cluster is moved to Pacific, cephadm is enabled by default and ceph-ansible can't be used anymore.

Do we want to support (upstream of course), fresh deployment based on ceph-ansible ?
(Note that we don't have any CI anymore, hence we're not able to catch any bug on container promotions).

Let's talk more about it, in any case a downstream cherry-pick works for me.

> This change doesn't remove it, for an existing environment deployed using ceph-ansible 

I understand. 

> Do we want to support (upstream of course), fresh deployment based on ceph-ansible ?

Yes, because we said we would when W GA'd. Upstream W is a transitional release.

https://docs.openstack.org/project-deploy-guide/tripleo-docs/latest/features/ceph_config.html#deploying-an-overcloud-with-ceph

The above doc should be updated (cephadm can do it all now) but we pledged to support both cephadm and ceph-ansible in wallaby upstream so we shouldn't retroactively remove that support. Downstream is a different story so doing this downstream is justified IMO.

> (Note that we don't have any CI anymore, hence we're not able to catch any bug on container promotions).

I understand. And with the release of Wallaby we said we deprecated it. 

However, deprecating doesn't mean backporting a change to remove support later. If someone settled on Wallaby with ceph-ansible and read what we said we'd do, then they should expect to be able to deploy latest W with ceph-ansible understanding that it's deprecated but not impossible.

That's why I think we should do this downstream only.

designate_tempest_plugin/tests/api/v2/te.message: This test is trying to create "transfer request" for non existing zone ID and it's not so clear from the test name, I would recommend to rename the test name.
It seems consistent with the existing tests. I am fine with it.
I think it's understandable and the name shouldn't be so complicated.

I think it's too much assertions we don't really need and that a simple single line:
self.assertRaises(lib_exc.NotFound,self.client.create_transfer_request,data_utils.rand_uuid())
would be enough.
maybe, but I want to cover all the options like in the other tests.

We typically try to avoid assertEqual on message strings. For one reason, if the cloud being tested has translations turned on, all of these string tests will fail. Also, the content of these strings can change over time without impacting the functionality. I.e. it may have a period added to the end of the sentence, or additional details may be appended to the string by error handlers.
So, for those reasons I would prefer we don't do the "message" assertion on line 518, but I am fine with the others.

designate_tempest_plugin/tests/scenario/.message: Depends on my comment in L109, not sure that "ignore_errors" is in place here.
It should be included and this is fine.
The truth is, I don't need the Cleanup because I delete the transfer_request at the end of the test and check if it relates to the transfer_accept, and erases it right after it.

According our discussion, the Designate logic we've found is that the Designate deletes transfer request" automatically after it was used, means some other user accepted zone transfer.
If the above is correct, then why do we need to delete the transfer here by ourselves?
I've added an assertion to ensure that the status changes to "COMPLETE" after we've accepted the request.
Since this is scenario test, end-to-end is implied.

roles/kubernetes/tasks/control-plane.yml.message:
I think we need to add `force: true` below this.  The reason for this because it's possible we run this on an environment that already has this file, and it will fail because the destination file exists.

https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/collections/ansible/builtin/file_module.html#parameter-force

"Force the creation of the symlinks in two cases: the source file does not exist (but will appear later); the destination exists and is a file (so, we need to unlink the path file and create symlink to the src file in place of it)."

In the case, we need to handle the second case, since we are transitioning from static file to symbolic link 😊

It returns a set not a list so this seems a little confusing.  Perhaps:

 Get a list of Ceph pools as a set

?  (also, s/ceph/Ceph/ please)

difference({""}) excludes "" as a possible pool name.  I added this to handle an edge case where list_pools() finds no ceph pools and returns "\n\n". We probably won't ever see this in the wild, but I saw it in my small testing environment. The key issue here is that when list_pools() returns "\n\n", ceph_pools becomes {""}, which is not falsy, and does not trigger the "No pools found" check on line 89. 

If we remove difference({""}), then we can also remove (or change) the if statement on line 89.  The edge case of finding no ceph pools will be resolved by get_inconsistent_pgs(pool), which will raise an exception because `rados list-inconsistent-pgs ""` fails. 

If list_pools() returns one or more pool names, difference({""}) will have no effect.
Would suggest logging *before* you invoke `ceph pg repair` so the operator has a hope of knowing what happened if ceph pg repair fails and this logging call is never reached.

plugins/module_utils/openstack.py.message: Why providing a log_level with four different options if only 'DEBUG' is ever used?

Ansible provides functions self.ansible.log() and self.ansible.debug() for writing log/debug output. Why not using those instead of writing to a log file directly? (really curious!) openstacksdk's enable_logging() provides a 'handlers' parameter which could be used for implementing this kind of redirect from openstacksdk to self.ansible.log/debug.

Well, we would need to read/parse log to re-emit entries with proper level (imagine running playbook in non verbose mode and still willing to access debug SDK log). We can also simply return log content as return parameter. But we always need to think about sensitive data in the log and eventual need for sanitizing. 
Anyway here we first wanted to start gathering log at all so that from that we can move towards one or another way of returning this to user.
ack, lets add option sdk_log_path. We can add other options for logging later.

Because of Ansible design (for modules) those calls go to syslog on the target host and not to the playbook output (this is different for plugins). And even that is not always working properly (i.e. not in Mac). Ideallly we want to give this info back to invoker, but that has few conceptual and security issues as well.

We could return sdk log to invoker in a 'sdk_log' field?

For example, we would pass a custom handler to enable_logging() which simply appends all records to a list or something. We extend/implement exit{,_json}/fail{,_json} functions to automatically add this list to what is returned to the Ansible controller.

I was wondering:

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Instance creator would be the lessee. Owner, in ironic's data model is just that, who owns the machine and has overriding interest in it's use. As a result, I don't think we would ever imply someone to become an owner of a machine.

Does that make sense?

tripleoclient/v1/tripleo_deploy.py.message: This file is only used for undercloud install / upgrade. I'm not sure we need to check for anything Ceph related during the undercloud install / upgrade do we?

I see this file is actually used in standalone [1], which is where I was able to test in the first place this patch.
Of course we don't have to make any check during the upgrade scenario, for 2 reasons:

1. ceph is supposed to be an external task
2. the upgrade at this point is not managed by tripleo

However, any stack update runs part of the ceph deployment process (e.g, pools, keys, clients, additional daemons), and make this kind of check doesn't hurt (you can just make sure your overcloud heat variables are consistent), but in any case, I added this check in this file because of the standalone, which is run with something like:

```
sudo openstack tripleo deploy \
  --templates \
  --local-ip=192.168.24.1/24 \
  -e /usr/share/openstack-tripleo-heat-templates/environments/standalone/standalone-tripleo.yaml \
```

It occurs to me that you may be looking for DCO enforcement in Gerrit hosted projects. Gerrit actually supports this as a built in requirement for pushing changes and is probably a much better solution for you to this problem.

You want to update your Gerrit ACL file (eg https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/src/branch/master/gerrit/acls/starlingx/app-kubevirt.config) to include:

  [receive]
      requireSignedOffBy = true
      
Then Gerrit will check this when changes are pushed and you get very early feedback on this instead of waiting for CI to run.

This role is primarily useful for other code review systems that don't have built in DCO checking. If you intend on using this role with projects hosted outside of Gerrit you can ignore everything I just said :)

roles/validate-commit-message-guidelines.message:
If this role's purpose is to assert OpenStack's guidelines on commit messages I think it should live in an openstack repo instead of zuul's library of roles.

Zuul itself doesn't follow these guidelines so it feels weird to ship a standard role that asserts they should be followed.

A long time ago OpenStack tried to enforce some of these rules with the "hacking" tool. But they were unpopular because whether or not a period is at the end of the first line of a commit message is often unimportant compared to the rest of the change.

It was also problematic because if you ran `tox -epep8` (which ran hacking) locally before pushing you typically ran that command before committing which meant you'd pass pep8 locally then possibly fail in CI. In general I think it became accepted that if a commit message was problematic reviewers could request that it be updated.

Personally I find it far more important for commit messages to call out why a change is being made. The formatting is far less important compared to this critical detail and a linter isn't going to be able to evaluate that. But "why?" is important because it informs reviewers with important information to assess if the change actually improves the situation it aims to address. It also serves as important historical information should the code need to be updated later and there is confusion over why it was written the way it was.
Makes a lot of sense. This pattern is kinda inherited to StarlingX though. Not sure if other opendev projects follow the same idea, but I'll move it to openstack-zuul-jobs.

In network v2 I used the "tags" field on neutron resources to set "metadata", such as stack_name, hostname for ports belonging to a specific node, service_vip for ovn_dbs/redis VIPs etc. This is how idempotency is maintained, and it allowed to add cleanup tasks. It does query for ports with tags for example all ports with tags: ['tripleo_stack=my_overcloud', 'tripleo_net_vip=true'] to know what overcloud virtual IPs ports to delete on stack delete. See for example the cleanup method[1] for ovn_bridge_mac ports, and [2] for deleting ports when a node is unprovisioned.

files/openstack-cli-server/openstack-cli.message:
So I think this will end up serializing all the would-be-parallel osc commands that I run in parallel right? Maybe that won't matter if the startup overhead is nearly zero, but I'm pretty sure we're overlapping more than just startup time right now based on my seat-of-the-pants feelings. Not just OSC overhead, but also waiting on slow replies from servers. Parallelizing the execution of those not only helps with OSC overhead, but also latency due to slowness in the servers.

Presumably we could just use a queue in here to fork off some workers and let one handle each accept? Not sure how much complexity you want to build into a server written in devstack to speed up a slow python program, but I also don't want to lose the benefit we get by doing things like flavor and volume type creation in parallel.

Yeah, I think you're right. I just replied to the mailing list thread too, but even with with this limitation it's still faster than the regular client. Parallel execution does make the osc waits worse, but it's still less than half what it is without the service. If we could get it back to what it was with serial execution we might save about another minute.

After reviewing the documentation, the previous patch, and the mysql source code - I believe we should just add a new config option here.

For 1, the max_connections is already added to the default section but we cannot be sure that users will have upgraded their database versions to a new enough version that accepts the max_total_connections option. It was introduced in 8.0.27, but 8.0.19 is what was shipped with Focal and so we must assume that some users are still running a version that does not have this option available. As such, we'll also need to check if the package version is capable of having this option enabled and when it is capable we will then use the max_total_connections option. 

For 2, the max_total_connections and max_connections are not mutually exclusive with one another. The max_total_connections option is ultimately a limiter that governs the total number of incoming connections to the router service.

I believe that you need both options in here.
Change default value to 1024 and change the description in config.yaml
Discussed with Nobuto. We will confirm it with engineering team again when backport to stable branch.

There's no need to have the charm configuration option exactly match the backend's configuration option. It can be abstracted into a nice definition, such as max_connections. I see no value to be gained by changing the name of this configuration option, in fact it causes burden on the operator; if they have set this prior to upgrading to this charm version they would have to remember to set the new configuration option to the correct value.

Hi Billy,

max_connections and max_total_connections are supported by mysql-router 8.0. But it seems the former one would be replaced by the latter some day. The usage of max_connections is also a little different. It is designed to put under each routing instead of [DEFAULT] section, although it is acceptable too.

https://dev.mysql.com/doc/mysql-router/8.0/en/mysql-router-conf-options.html#option_mysqlrouter_max_connections

https://dev.mysql.com/doc/mysql-router/8.0/en/mysql-router-conf-options.html#option_mysqlrouter_max_total_connections

``
The legacy max_connections option sets a value per routing instance, such as one value for read-only, and another for write-only. The max_total_connections option sets one value for all routing instances combined.
``

And max_connections is not configurable in charm until the latest stable/jimmy release last week. It is implemented in this wishlist. I also left the message there and try to provide the patch before the release day to avoid the situation you mentioned. Unfortunately, it's too late to be included in the latest release.
https://bugs.launchpad.net/charm-mysql-router/+bug/1929826. 


That's why I would like to provide this patch to fix it asap and backport back to stable/jimmy.


Some options here, please advise which way is better.

Option1: Suggest user use the legacy option and close #1969927

Option2: Don't change the name in charm but we can map "max_connections" to "max_total_connections" in mysql-router.conf. But I am a little worried it would confuse user. Because both of them are supported by mysql-router now.

Option3: Add one more configuration in charm-mysqlrouter and map to max_total_connections.

Option4: Change the naming in charm.

It's pity that we did not find the new configuration earlier. `max_connections` is just been supported in charm-mysql-router with the latest release couple weeks ago. I also prefer to reserve only 1 configuration and `max_total_connections` is my  preference. 

Could we replace `max_connections` to `max_total_connections` and submit SRU? This feature is only available in the stable/jimmy branch now. If it is not acceptable, I will vote to maintain "max_connections" in charm and generate the configuration based on the mysql-router version. 

- version >= 8.0.27,  generate `max_total_connections` in mysql-router.conf
- otherwise, generate `max_connections` in mysql-router.conf

I want to disagree here because none of the charm applications are currently using more than 1 routing instance - they all just use port 3306 (as best I can tell if you know better please let me know). So for all applications we are using today, these two options are equivalent in practice.

Since these options are seldom used, if we keep both, people are likely to just always set both of them or only set one and then if we later need to deprecate one (which is not unlikely since upstream has indicated max_connections is deprecated) then we may break existing deployments when we remove the option if they have only set one and not both options.

In line with the idea that charms should provide a simplified and opinionated configuration I think having both options is going to be confusing and we are better off sticking to a single option and intelligently writing a configuration file from that option based on the software version.

I'd like to defer to Billy for a final decision on whether to stick with a single 'max-connections' option or not given this extra new information. I've got a more detailed/considered explanation of why I feel strongly this way below:


For clarity, mysql-router listens on 4 ports which are each a routing 'instance'

base_port (3306): mysql "classic" rw (read-write) 
base_port+1 (3307): mysql "classic" ro (read-only) -> Connects to SECONDARY node if possible otherwise PRIMARY node
base_port+2 (3308): mysql "x" protocol rw (read-write)
base_port+3 (3309): mysql "x" protocol ro (read-only)

The read-write ports connect only to the PRIMARY node, the read-only ports connect if possible to one of the two SECONDARY nodes but will fallback to a PRIMARY node if none are available.

The original 'max_connections' option sets an individual limit for each of these ports but is documented as deprecated in favour of 'max_total_connections' which sets a combined limit for all 4 ports with no sub-limit. I did test and at least in 8.0.29 the two options do work together so you can set max_connections to say 256 for each port and then max_total_connections to 512 so you can use a total of 512 connections accross all 4 instances but a maximum of 256 per instance. 

If an application was actually using both the readwrite+readonly ports (remember that currently no charm does) it could in theory be useful to have a sub-limit between the two however since the readonly port can connect to any of the 3 servers it doesn't really cleanly enforce the client only using up some percentage of a target servers max_connections in any way. So given both that and the fact no one is really using it, this seems to have very limited utility versus just limiting the total number of connections to all servers. 

Hence why I feel the best option would be to have a single 'max-connections' option which sets either max_connections or max_total_connections based on the currently installed version so that we cleanly support both versions.

Note that this change in general (to use max_total_connetions at all) won't give us any benefit right now but may help if they actually deprecate and remove the old max_connections option at some point - this seems not entirely unlikely as we are shipping all upstream point releases as an SRU and they frequently break things like this in contravention with normal SRU policies. (See Bug #1914299, Bug #1971565 for examples).

As a final reason for this, if they do later remove the max_connections option upstream and then we removed the same from the charm existing deployments that needed the increased limit it may silently break the environment on upgrade if we remove the option - alternatively we would have to keep both options and configure max_total_connections based on the maximum of both config options. In general this seems likely to lead to people either setting only one of them and not both (and potentially being broken later) - or much more likely people will needlessly set both options to the same value. Which doesn't feel like a great user experience either.

I have suggestions for changes to the patch whichever option we decide on but will post that as a separate comment.
Added a comment in support of keeping the single max-connections option

I think Trent has convinced me that a single option is best as the two parameters are effectively equivalent 99% of the time. The simplicity for the user of only having one knob to tune is a better user experience in most cases.
This looks good to me but would like to get Billys feedback too since he has been closely involved.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Also seems someone else submitted a similar patch https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/zuul/+/809200 , so I'm not the only one seeing this.
I did some testing and what you see happens when merging with a merge commit while my case is with merge-rebase. squash mode is handled even different. this needs more thought and testing

The format of the commit message depends on the merge-mode. What you describe is only valid for merge-mode=squash-merge, with this patch applied the information will be missing for merge commits. Sadly it is also non-trivial for zuul to figure out which merge-mode is effectively being used, since it not only depends on the project configuration in zuul, but also on the configuration within github.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: User can use tag and/or namespace to store whatever data they want. Storing additional info in images is not required.

Ok, so you will probably agree that we can remove labels 

build-date
kolla_version

As you said "Storing additional info in images is not required."

Moreover kolla_version can be several commits if you are building from a git, but version will be still same.
Build-date is also not usefull as I can build several images daily but not additional info after the date (build no.).

In my proposal there can be one commit label ..and you can check exact commit upstream od downstream git:
 - Author
 - Date
 - Kolla-version
 - Description 
 - Whatever

So let's replace it by commit, or remove if "Storing additional info in images is not required."

Agree with Michal and also can see your point, but if you really need to have the commit id in your images you can just extend the labels code block with any other label you need https://github.com/openstack/kolla/blob/master/docker/base/Dockerfile.j2#L2

Basically - kolla_version is there, for users to understand what version of Kolla has been used to build that image, right? Can't we just update that (to include both version and git commit sha) - since we already encourage users to stop using tagged versions and fetch git branch code?
Guys, please, could you share your opinion ? Thanks.

git log -1 > file, merge that file into template_overrides where it will be present in some block in every image

then use generated template_overrides during build.
So just update the kolla_version tag (instead of introducing new one) and let's get over with it?

Ah, no that's not possible .. kolla_version is used in bash scripts of kolla-ansible to for example cleanup old images.

./tools/cleanup-images:43:            KOLLA_IMAGES="$(sudo docker images -a --filter "label=kolla_version" --format "{{.ID}}")"
./tools/cleanup-images:53:            KOLLA_IMAGES="$(sudo docker images -a --filter "label=kolla_version" --format "{{.Repository}}\t{{.ID}}" | grep -E "$2" | awk '{print $2}')"
./tools/cleanup-images:58:            KOLLA_IMAGES="$(sudo docker images -a --filter "label=kolla_version=${2}" --format "{{.ID}}")"
./tools/cleanup-containers:3:containers_running=$(sudo docker ps --filter "label=kolla_version" --format "{{.Names}}")
./tools/cleanup-containers:14:    containers_to_kill=$(sudo docker ps --filter "label=kolla_version" --format "{{.Names}}" -a | grep -E "$1" | awk '{print $1}')
./tools/cleanup-containers:18:    containers_to_kill=$(sudo docker ps --filter "label=kolla_version" --format "{{.Names}}" -a)
./ansible/roles/prune-images/tasks/prune_images.yml:7:      label: kolla_version

BTW, removing kolla_version or other labels cannot be done that easily because it will modify the ABI of the images and possibly break some user tasks such as cleaning images or filtering during upgrades

I totally understand your issue and have mixed feelings about the change, If kolla_version is empty on source builds, you could try to extend the behavior of version.py to apply the commit into the kolla_version label without creating new labels. Just an idea...

Point is that we have downstream branches where we are commiting our changes. In case we don't want to merge always some bugfix or feature from upstream, we are rebasing against upstream to have commits on top of the upstream branch - so we can't push normally because of rebase.

So on the end we are tagging every rebase we've done (commit is de facto same reference). From this tags we are building images and tag it by openstack version and commit.

This change just do this automatically (now we have pipelines which is doing also - but it's not kolish).

So, my idea was that if there is kolla version ..which is not describing anything ..because images are generated from git) ..commit label from which is image built can be also present, and as I said, it is more specific than kolla version and build date.
Ah, yeah you are right ... just kolla_version name of label is  little misleading.
nvm, just checked and source builds also have kolla_version data
So, what now, better ? It's not breaking nothing
Exactly this is my point ! I don't know why it's so awful and unwanted :/

I am not saying that it is not present ..just saying that kolla_version is not changing after every commit ...so the version will be same as for image which is built one hour later from different commit which is fixing some issue .. (as recent sasl binaries missing) ..

So, it means I will build several images from several git commits in branch for example yoga and if I will not tag images..I am not able to know from which commit I've built. Moreover it's useful to ask customer. Hey could you inspect container and tell me the commit which is defined as a label ? 

kolla_version is bumped only sometimes.

do not pretend that it's a big problem to add one label is too hard and breaking something.

I know that this can be configured ..but that's the thing ... simple change in a code is nicer.

And easy backportable even if downstream users as we are do this manually.

And it's nice also for upstream...every time I can checkout commit and see from which commit it was built.
It's only listing images that have this label, that should be all right?

nodepool/driver/aws/adapter.py.message: It's probably unlikely to hit but the terminate_instances can take up to 1000 instance ids with the note that's recommended to break this up into smaller batches. What do you think about limiting this to 50 per batch?

Documentation states that when the delete instances call fails no instance is deleted. So I think for leaked resources we should stay with the direct deletion without the background thread. So what do you think about adding a direct_delete flag here and depending on this put it into the delete queue or directly terminate the instance?

I guess the other requests are short enough that we don't need to farm them out to the thread pool too? Otherwise we may just shift the problem from instance create to making a volume or whatever other little bits are involved.

That said I suspect that is why deletes are now batched and the other tasks are quick enough to not really matter.

Yeah: create takes > 1 sec so that's bad.  Delete is faster so it's not a problem.  But we batch it because fewer requests are better regardless.  The only other requests that happen during the normal lifecycle are quota checks (which are heavily cached) and instance lists (also cached).
But we set timeout=10 so it does raise Empty in that case.
The docs say this exception is only raised with non blocking gets. We block above so this try except shouldn't be necessary.

It looks like timeouts to delete are handled in the state machine state machine :) But that means we don't have to worry about extra deletes for a single instance ending up in this queue. Instead we'll try once until the timeout. Then later nodepool should notice the deletion failed and try again which will put it in this queue again after it was removed and the attempt expired.
